description: Your ability to create clear, visually appealing interfaces using hierarchy, typography, color, and layout principles.

scoreMeaning.strong: You create visually clear interfaces with strong hierarchy and consistent visual language. Your designs guide users' attention effectively.
scoreMeaning.decent: You understand visual design basics and can create functional UIs, but may struggle with hierarchy or consistency across screens.
scoreMeaning.needsImprovement: You're still learning visual design principles. Your interfaces may lack clear hierarchy or consistent styling.

strong: Document your visual design system (type scale, color tokens, spacing rules).
Create reusable component patterns for common UI elements.
Mentor others on visual hierarchy and layout principles.
Audit existing product screens for visual consistency and propose improvements.
decent: Define a simple type scale and apply it consistently across 3-5 key screens.
Audit current product colors and map them to semantic roles (primary, error, success).
Take one existing screen and improve its visual hierarchy using size and contrast.
Run a quick 5-second test with a peer to see what they notice first.
needsImprovement: Learn basic visual hierarchy principles (size, contrast, spacing).
Study one well-designed product and identify how they use typography and color.
Practice creating clear visual hierarchy in simple layouts.
Take a visual design course or read about Gestalt principles.

examplesOfStrong: You create interfaces where users can quickly identify primary actions.
You maintain consistent visual language across all product screens.
You use spacing and typography to guide users through complex information.
examplesOfWeak: Screens have unclear visual hierarchy - everything looks equally important.
Inconsistent spacing, colors, or typography across different screens.
Users struggle to find primary actions or important information.
